answer_html: \(\displaystyle I=\frac{1}{2} x (\sin (\ln x) - \cos (\ln x)) + C\)
hints_html:
Start with the substitution u = ln x.

Next, do integration by parts twice to solve for the integral you wound up with after the substitution.
hints_latex:
Next, do integration by parts twice to solve for the integral you wound
up with after the substitution.
hints_raw:
Start with the substitution ''u'' = ''ln x''.
Next, do integration by parts twice to solve for the integral you wound up with after the substitution.
question: 2 (d)
sols_html:
The integral will become less complicated if we make a substitution \(u = \ln x\).

First substitution

If u = ln x then \(du = (1/x) \ dx\) so \(dx = x \ du = e^u \ du\). For the last equality we solved \(u = \ln x\) for \(x\). Therefore,

\[\begin{aligned} I = \int \sin(\ln x) \ dx = \int e^u \sin u \ du\end{aligned}\]

First integration by parts

To find this integral, we will need to integrate by parts twice.

Let \(f = e^u\) with \(df = e^u \ du\) and \(dg = \sin u \ du\) with \(g = -\cos u\). Then

\[\begin{aligned} I &= fg - \int g df = -e^u \cos u - \int e^u (-\cos u) \ du \\ &= -e^u \cos u + \int e^u \cos u \ du\end{aligned}\]

Second integration by parts

We repeat the process on the second integral, this time with \(f = e^u\) and \(df = e^u \ du\), and \(dg = \cos u \ du\) with \(g = \sin u\). Now we find:

\[\begin{aligned} I = -e^u \cos u + (e^u \sin u - \int e^u \sin u \ du)\end{aligned}\]

Inspect the result

We recognize the integral above as I! We can now solve for I:

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle I = -e^u \cos u + e^u \sin u - I\end{aligned}\]

so

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle 2I = e^u \sin u - e^u \cos u\end{aligned}\]

Then

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle I = \frac{1}{2} e^u (\sin u-\cos u) + C\end{aligned}\]

We added the arbitrary constant C because we are computing an indefinite integral.

Bring x back

Finally, the integral we desire can be found by replacing \(u\) by \(\ln x\) so that \(e^u = x\):

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle I = \frac{1}{2} x (\sin (\ln x) - \cos (\ln x)) + C\end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
The integral will become less complicated if we make a substitution <math>u = \ln x </math>.

===== First substitution =====

If ''u'' = ''ln x'' then <math>du = (1/x) \ dx</math> so <math>dx = x \ du = e^u \ du</math>. For the last equality we solved <math>u = \ln x</math> for <math>x</math>. Therefore,

:<math>I = \int \sin(\ln x) \ dx = \int e^u \sin u \ du</math>

===== First integration by parts =====

To find this integral, we will need to integrate by parts twice.

Let <math>f = e^u</math> with <math>df = e^u \ du</math> and <math>dg = \sin u \ du</math> with <math>g = -\cos u</math>. Then 

:<math>\begin{align}
I &= fg - \int g df = -e^u \cos u - \int e^u (-\cos u) \ du \\
&= -e^u \cos u + \int e^u \cos u \ du
\end{align} </math>

===== Second integration by parts =====

We repeat the process on the second integral, this time with <math>f = e^u</math> and <math>df = e^u \ du</math>, and <math>dg = \cos u \ du</math> with <math>g = \sin u</math>. Now we find:

:<math>I = -e^u \cos u + (e^u \sin u - \int e^u \sin u \ du)</math>


===== Inspect the result =====

We recognize the integral above as ''I''! We can now solve for ''I'':

:<math> \displaystyle
I = -e^u \cos u + e^u \sin u - I
</math>
so

:<math> \displaystyle
2I = e^u \sin u - e^u \cos u
</math>

Then

:<math> \displaystyle
I = \frac{1}{2} e^u (\sin u-\cos u) + C
</math>

We added the arbitrary constant ''C'' because we are computing an indefinite integral.


===== Bring ''x'' back =====

Finally, the integral we desire can be found by replacing <math>u</math> by <math>\ln x</math> so that <math>e^u = x</math>:

:<math>\displaystyle
I = \frac{1}{2} x (\sin (\ln x) - \cos (\ln x)) + C 
</math>
statement_html:
Integration: Short Answer Problems - Evaluate the following integrals: state if a definite integral does not exist; use limits for improper integrals. (full marks for correct answer; work must be shown for partial marks)

\(\displaystyle I_d = \int \sin(\ln x)\,dx\)
